text.tspan: 1. Upon admission of a resident into the facility, the Facility Administrator collects a list of medications from either the healthcare provider (hospitals, skilled nursing facilities, or primary care physician) or resident’s family.
2. The actual medications are also collected upon admission.
3. All medications, including over-the-counter, are kept in locked storage at all times.
4. All medications must be stored in accordance with label instructions (refrigerate, room temperature, out of direct sunlight, etc.).
5. Medications requiring refrigeration are stored in a separate section of the refrigerator (or in a separate refrigerator if available) and clearly marked.
6. The facility must ensure that the resident receives the necessary medication as soon as the resident is admitted, including the day of admission, with no missed dosage, based on last dosage taken.

7. The Facility Administrator must record all medications received into the Centrally Stored Medication Record (Form LIC622 in CA). The form includes the following information: Resident Name, Date of Birth, Age, Sex,

Admission Date, and Attending Physician, with data up to here displayed as header information; Medication Name, Strength, Indication, Instruction, Special Storage Instruction if any (Optional field), Expiration Date, Fill Date,

Start Date, Quantity Received, Prescribing Physician, Prescription Number, Number of Refills, Pharmacy Name, Pharmacy Address, Pharmacy Phone Number, Bottle Status (Current or Depleted), and Comments.
8. The log should have a date/time stamp whenever it is updated with the indication of what data is updated. Alternatively, each medication data can have an update date/time stamp.
9. The Centrally Stored Medication Record must be updated and maintained up to date as the medication bottles are depleted and refilled, and new medications are received.
10. The Facility Administrator must prepare and maintain a Medication Assistance Record (MAR) for each resident to ensure adherence to medication administration as prescribed by the physician(s).

11. The MAR will include the following information: Resident Name, Date of Birth, Age, Sex, Admission Date, and Attending Physician, with data up to here displayed as header information, Medication Name, Strength, Indiction,

Instruction including frequency taken per day and when taken (AM, PM, Bedtime, or specific time, with Meals or other specific instructions), Start Date, Stop Date, Medication Status (Active or Inactive) and comments.
12. The log should have a date/time stamp whenever it is updated with the indication of what data is updated. Alternatively, each medication data can have an update date/time stamp.

13. Each medication will be grouped into either Routine or PRN (As Needed) catagory. Routine meds are taken on a regular basis, mostly daily although some exceptions may exist such as every other day or on Monday,
Wednesday, and Friday as examples, as prescribed by the physician. PRN meds are only taken if needed on a given day/situation.
14. All medications taken are noted as such, for each dose.
15. The FA or its designee (can be a Backup FA or Caregiver) will prepare the resident’s meds on a daily basis, sometime the day before they are administered.

16. Each resident has a dedicated medication bin in a locked medicine cabinet. The meds are placed into a cup for each dosage to be administered throughout the day. Each resident can have 1 to 6 medication passes
per day, with most residents having 2-3 passes per day. The frequency of medication passes depends on physician orders.
